Sutton Hoo helmet
Latest reconstruction (built 1970–1971) of the Sutton Hoo helmet
Material Iron, bronze, tin, gold, silver, garnets
Weight 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) (estimated)
Discovered 1939
Sutton Hoo, Suffolk
52°05′22″N 1°20′17″E﻿ / ﻿52.08934°N 1.33806°E﻿ / 52.08934; 1.33806
Discovered by Charles Phillips
Present location British Museum, London
Registration 1939,1010.93
This article is about the archaeological find. For the artwork, see Sutton Hoo Helmet (sculpture).

The Sutton Hoo helmet is a decorated Anglo-Saxon helmet which was discovered during the 1939 excavation of the Sutton Hoo ship burial. It was buried around 625 and is widely believed to have been the helmet of King Rædwald of East Anglia, and its elaborate decoration may have given it a secondary function akin to a crown. The helmet is "the most iconic object" from "one of the most spectacular archaeological discoveries ever made," and one of the most important Anglo-Saxon artefacts ever found.[1][2] Its visage features eyebrows, nose, and moustache, creating the image of a man joined by a dragon's head to become a soaring dragon with outstretched wings. It has become a symbol of the Dark Ages and also "of Archaeology in general."[3] It was excavated as hundreds of rusted fragments, and was first displayed following an initial reconstruction in 1945–46, and then in its present form after a second reconstruction in 1970–71.

The helmet and the other finds from Sutton Hoo were determined by a treasure trove inquest to be the property of Edith Pretty, who owned the site of the ship-burial. She donated all the objects to the British Museum, where they were conserved and put on display. The helmet was on view in Room 41 in 2018.[4][5][6]

Background[edit]

The ship impression during the 1939 excavation
Main article: Sutton Hoo

The helmet was buried among other regalia and instruments of power as part of a furnished ship burial, probably dating from the early seventh century. Although the man in the grave has not been identified, the contents of the grave point to its being that of a king.[7] It is generally thought most likely that Rædwald, the ruler of the East Angles, is the person buried in the ship, due to the proximity of the royal vill of Rendlesham[7] and as use of the site is believed to have been a time when he held power in England.

The ship had been hauled from the nearby river up the hill and lowered into a prepared trench.[8][9] Inside this, the helmet was wrapped in cloths and placed to the left of the head of the body.[10][11] An oval mound was constructed around the ship.[12] Long afterwards, the chamber roof collapsed violently under the weight of the mound, compressing the ship's contents into a seam of earth.[13]

It is thought that the helmet was shattered either by the collapse of the burial chamber or by the force of another object falling on it.[14][15] However, the fact that the helmet had shattered meant that it was possible to reconstruct it. Had the helmet been crushed before the iron had fully oxidised, leaving it still pliant, the helmet would have been squashed,[15][16] leaving it in a distorted shape similar to the Vendel[17] and Valsgärde[18] helmets.[19]

Description[edit]

Replica helmet showing designs 1, 2, 4 and 5, located (1) above the eyebrows and on the cheek guard, (2) on the skull cap, (4) on the cheek guard[note 1] and skull cap, and (5) on the face mask

The Sutton Hoo helmet, weighing an estimated 2.5 kg (5.5 lb),[20] was made of iron and covered with decorated sheets of tinned bronze.[21][22] Fluted strips of moulding divided the exterior into panels, each of which was stamped with one of five designs.[23][22] Two depict figural scenes, another two zoophormic interlaced patterns; a fifth pattern, known only from seven small fragments and incapable of restoration, is only known to occur once on an otherwise symmetrical helmet and may have been used to replace a damaged panel.[24][25] The existence of these five designs has been generally understood since the first reconstruction, published in 1947.[26][note 2] The succeeding three decades gave rise to an increased understanding of the designs and their parallels in contemporary imagery, allowing possible reconstructions of the full panels to be advanced, and through the second reconstruction their locations on the surface of the helmet to be redetermined.[25][33][34][35] As referred to below, the designs are numbered according to Rupert Bruce-Mitford's 1978 work.[25]

Construction[edit]

The core of the helmet was constructed of iron and consisted of a cap from which hung a face mask and cheek and neck guards.[21][36] The cap was "beaten up out of a single piece of metal."[37][note 3] On either side of it were hung iron cheek guards,[40][41] deep enough to "completely protect the side of the face"[42] and curved inward "both longitudinally and laterally."[43] Two hinges per side, possibly made of leather, supported these pieces,[44] allowing them to be pulled flush with the face mask and "completely enclose" the face.[42] A neck guard was attached to the back of the cap and made of two overlapping pieces: a shorter piece set inside the cap, over which attached a "broad fan-like portion" extending downwards, "straight from top to bottom but curved laterally to follow the line of the neck."[45] The inset portion afforded the neck guard extra movement, and like the cheek guards was attached to the cap by leather hinges.[45] Finally, the face mask was riveted to the cap on both sides and above the nose.[46] Two cutouts served as eye openings,[47] while a third opened into the hollow of the overlaid nose, thereby facilitating access to the two nostril-like holes underneath; though small, these holes would have been among the few sources of fresh air for the wearer.[48]

Atop the foundational layer of iron were placed decorative sheets of tinned bronze.[21][49] These sheets, divided into five figural or zoomorphic designs,[24][25] were manufactured by the pressblech process.[50][51][52] Preformed dies similar to the Torslunda plates[53] were covered with thin metal which, through applied force, took up the design underneath;[54][55] identical designs could thus be "mass-produced" from the same die, allowing for their repeated use on the helmet and other objects.[50][note 4] Fluted strips of white alloyed moulding—possibly of tin and copper, and possibly swaged[23][60]—divided the designs into framed panels, held to the helmet by bronze rivets.[23][49] The two strips running from front to back alongside the crest were gilded.[61][62] The edges of the helmet were further protected by U-shaped brass tubing, fastened by swaged bronze clips[21][63] and themselves further holding in place the pressblech panels that shared edges with the helmet.[64]

A final layer of adornments added to the helmet a crest, eyebrows, nose and mouth piece, and three dragon heads. A hollow iron crest ran across the top of the cap and terminated at front and back.[40][37] It was made of "D-sectioned" tubing[40][37] and consisted of two parts, an inverted "U-shaped" piece into which a "flat bottom strip" was placed.[39] As no traces of solder remain, the crest may have been either forged or shrunk on to the cap.[65] From either end of the crest extended an iron tang, to each of which was riveted a gilded dragon head.[66] That on the front was made of cast bronze, while the one on the rear was made of "a different alloy, and now consists largely of tin oxide."[67] A third dragon head, also of cast bronze, faced upwards on the front of the helmet and broke the plane between face mask and cap;[68] its neck rested on the face mask, while under its eyes it was held to the cap by "a massive rivet shank."[69] To either side of the neck projected a hollow cast bronze eyebrow, into each of which was inlaid parallel silver wires.[70][71][72][73] Terminal boar heads were gilded, as were the undersides of the eyebrows,[74] where individual bronze cells held square garnets.[75][71][72] The eyebrows were riveted on, both to the cap at their outer ends and to the tang of a nose and mouth piece which extended upwards underneath the neck of the dragon head.[76] This tang was itself riveted to the cap,[77] one of five attachment points for the cast bronze[78] nose and mouth piece.[79] Both sides of the nose featured "two small round projecting plates,"[80] connected by fluted and swaged strips, and concealing rivets.[81] An inlaid strip of wire extended the length of the nasal ridge, next to which the "background was punched down" and filled with niello or another metallic inlay,[82] leaving "triangles in relief" that were silvered.[78] A tracer (a "rather blunt chisel . . . used chiefly for outlining"[83]) was used to provide a grooved border on each side.[78] Running horizontally aside the nasal bridge were three punched circles per side, inlaid with silver and possibly surrounded by niello.[78] Beneath these circles, also running horizontally from the center of the nose to its sides were chased[78] "alternate rows of plain flutings and billeted strips which run obliquely between the central strip and a billeted lower edge."[48] This same pattern is repeated in vertical fashion on the moustache.[78][84] The curve along the bevelled lower lip, in turn, repeats the circled pattern used on the nasal bridge.[85][86] Excepting the portions covered by the eyebrows and dragon head,[47] or adorned with silver or niello,[note 5] the nose and mouth piece was heavily gilded,[78][84] which is suggested by the presence of mercury to have been done with the fire-gilding method.[82]

Breaking the symmetry of the helmet are subtle differences in the two eyebrows, and in the methods employed to fashion the cloisonné garnets. The dexter and sinister eyebrows, though at first glance identical, may have been "manufactured in different ways while being intended to look essentially the same."[90] The dexter brow is approximately 5 millimeters shorter than the sinister, and contained 43 rather than 46 inlaid silver wires and one or two fewer garnets.[91][note 6] Gilding on the dexter eyebrow was "reddish in colour" against the "yellowish" hue of the sinister,[93] while the latter contains both trace amounts of mercury and a tin corrosion product which are absent from its counterpart. Moreover, while the individual bronze cells into which the garnets are set, both on the dexter brow and on three of the four remaining dragon eyes, are underlain by small pieces of "hatched gold foil,"[75][91] those on the sinister side, and the sinister eye of the upper dragon head, have no such backing.[94] The gold backing served to reflect light back through the garnets, increasing their lustre and deepening their colour.[95] Where this backing was missing on the sinister eyebrow and one dragon eye, the luminosity of the garnets would be "substantially dimmed" by direct placement against the bronze.[96]

Dragon motifs[edit]

The winged dragon motif from the front of the helmet, with eyebrows for wings and the nose and mouth piece for body and tail

Three dragon heads are represented on the helmet. Two bronze-gilt dragon heads feature on either end of the iron crest running from the front to the rear of the skull cap.[39] The third sits at the junction between the two eyebrows, facing upward and given fuller form by the eyebrows, nose and moustache to create the impression of a dragon in flight.[91] There it soars upwards in the "central and most dramatic feature of the entire helmet," baring its teeth at the "snake-like dragon" flying down the crest.[97]

To the extent that the helmet is jewelled, such decoration is largely confined to the elements associated with the dragons.[98] Convex garnets sunk into the heads give the dragons red eyes.[70][99] The eyebrows are likewise inlaid with square garnets on their under edges, continuing outwards on each side to where they terminate in gilded boars' heads;[75][71][72][100] in addition to their secondary decorative function as wings, the eyebrows may therefore take on a tertiary form as boars' bodies.[101] The subtle differences between the eyebrows, the sinister of which lacks the gold foil backing employed on the dexter, may suggest an allusion to the one-eyed god Odin;[102] seen in low light, with the garnets of only one eye reflecting light, the helmet may have itself seemed to have only one eye.[103][note 7]

More gold covers the eyebrows, nose and mouth piece, and dragon heads, as it does the two fluted strips that flank the crest.[68] The crest and eyebrows are further inlaid with silver wires.[106][107][108][109] Combined with the silvery colour of the tinned bronze, the effect was "an object of burnished silvery metal, set in a trelliswork of gold, surmounted by a crest of massive silver, and embellished with gilded ornaments, garnets and niello—in its way a magnificent thing and one of the outstanding masterpieces of barbaric art."[110]

Design 1: Dancing warriors[edit]

One of the four Torslunda plates, showing a horned figure similar to those in design 1. His missing right eye suggests that he is Odin.[note 8]

The dancing warriors scene is known from six fragments and occurs four times on the helmet.[111] It is seen on the two panels immediately above the eyebrows, accounting for five of the fragments. The sixth fragment is placed in the middle row of the dexter cheek guard, on the panel closest to the face mask;[111][112] the generally symmetrical nature of the helmet implies the design's position on the opposite side as well.[28][113][114] None of the six pieces show both warriors, although the "key fragment" depicts their crossed wrists.[115][116] A full reconstruction of the scene was inferred after the first reconstruction, when Rupert Bruce-Mitford spent six weeks in Sweden and was shown a nearly identical design on the then unpublished Valsgärde 7 helmet.[27][117][118][119][120][121][122]

Design 1 pictures two men "in civilian or ceremonial dress"[116] perhaps engaged in a spear or sword dance[123][124] "associated with the cult of Odin, the war-god."[125][126] Their outer hands each hold two spears, pointed towards their feet,[115] while their crossed hands grip swords.[27] The depiction suggests "intricate measures," "rhythm," and an "elasticity of . . . dance steps."[127] Their trailing outer legs and curved hips imply movement towards each other,[128][129] and they may be in the climax of the dance.[129] The prevalence of dance scenes with a "similarity of the presentation of the scheme of movement" in contemporary Scandinavian and Northern art suggests that ritual dances "were well-known phenomena."[130] Sword dances in particular were recorded among the Germanic tribes as early as the first century AD, when Tacitus wrote of "[n]aked youths who practice the sport bound in the dance amid swords and lances," a "spectacle" which was "always performed at every gathering."[131][132][127] Whatever the meaning conveyed by the Sutton Hoo example, the "ritual dance was evidently no freak of fashion confined to a particular epoch, but was practised for centuries in a more or less unchanged form."[133]

While many contemporary designs portray ritual dances,[134] at least three examples show scenes exceptionally similar to that on the Sutton Hoo helmet and contribute to the understanding of the depicted sword dance. The same design—identical but for a different type of spears held in hand,[135] a different pattern of dress,[136] and a lack of crossed spears behind the two men[123]—is found on the Valsgärde 7 helmet, while a small fragment of stamped foil from the eastern mound at Gamla Uppsala is "so close in every respect to the corresponding warrior on the Sutton Hoo helmet as to appear at first glance to be from the same die," and may even have been "cut by the same man."[137] The third similar design is one of the four Torslunda plates,[138] discovered in Öland, Sweden, in 1870.[139] This plate, which is complete and depicts a figure with the same attributes as on design 1, suggests the association of the men in the Sutton Hoo example with "the cult of Odin."[125][126] The Torslunda figure is missing an eye, which laser scanning revealed to have been removed by a "sharp cut, probably in the original model used for the mould."[140] Odin too lost an eye, thus evidencing the identification of the Torslunda figure as him, and the Sutton Hoo figures as devotees of him.[125][126][140]

Design 2: Rider and fallen warrior[edit]

The Pliezhausen bracteate shows a scene nearly identical to design 2.

Eight fragments represent all known instances of the second design, accounting for its placement on a like number of panels.[141] It is surmised to have originally appeared twelve times on the helmet,[142] although this theory assumes that the unidentified third design, which occupies one of the twelve panels, was a replacement for a damaged panel.[143] Assuming so, the pattern occupied eight spaces on the lowest row of the skull cap (i.e., all but the two showing design 1), and two panels, one atop the other rising towards the crest, in the centre of each side.[144][145][146] All panels showing design 2 appear to have been struck from the same die.[147] The horse and rider thus move in a clockwise direction around the helmet, facing towards the rear of the helmet on the dexter side, and towards the front on the sinister side.[147]

As substantial sections of design 2 are missing, particularly from the "central area,"[148] reconstruction relies in part on continental versions of the same scene.[149] In particular, similar scenes are seen on the Valsgärde 7[150] and 8[151] helmets, the Vendel 1 helmet,[143] and on the Pliezhausen bracteate.[152] The latter piece, in particular, is both complete and nearly identical to the Sutton Hoo design.[153][154] Although a mirror image, and lacking in certain details depicted in design 2 such as the sword carried by the rider and the scabbard worn by the fallen warrior,[155][156] it suggests other details such as the small shield held by the kneeling figure.[157]

Design 2 shows a mounted warrior, spear held overhead, trampling an enemy on the ground.[158] The latter leans upwards and, grasping the reins in his left hand, uses his right hand to thrust a sword into the chest of the horse.[158] Atop the horse's rump kneels a "diminutive human, or at least anthropomorphic figure."[158] The figure is stylistically similar to the horseman. Its arms and legs are positioned identically, and, together with the rider, it clutches the spear with its right hand.[158]

The iconographic meaning of design 2 is unknown. It may derive from Roman models,[159][160][161] which frequently depicted images of warriors trampling vanquished enemies.[162] The subsequent development of the design, which has been found in England, Sweden, and Germany, suggests that it carried a unique meaning broadly understood in Germanic tradition.[156] Whereas the Roman examples show riders in moments of unqualified victory,[163] in Germanic representations the scene is ambiguous.[151] The symbolism is unclear,[164][165] and elements of victory are combined with elements of defeat:[166][156] the rider directs his spear straight forward at an invisible enemy, not down at the visible enemy on the ground; though the enemy is trampled, the rider's horse is dealt a fatal wound; and a small and possibly divine figure hovers behind the rider, its body taking the form of a victorious swastika[note 9] while it seemingly guides the spear.[167] An overarching theme of the design may therefore be that of fate.[168][156] In this understanding the divine figure, possibly Odin, guides the warrior in battle, but does not completely free him from the deadly threats he faces.[168] The gods are themselves subject to the whims of fate, and can provide only limited help against the rider's enemies.[169]

Design 3: Unidentified figural scene[edit]

The seven unidentified fragments

Seven small fragments suggest a third figural scene somewhere on the Sutton Hoo helmet. They are nevertheless too small and ambiguous to allow for the reconstruction of the scene.[32] Its presence is suggested "not more than four times, and perhaps only once";[143] because other fragments demonstrate the occurrence of design 1[170] or design 2[171] on all seven available panels on the sinister side of the helmet, and on the forwardmost two panels on the dexter side (in addition to on the highest dexter panel), placement of design 3 "must have occurred towards the rear of the helmet"[143] on the dexter side.

That which remains of design 3 may suggest that a "variant rider scene" was employed to fix damage to a design 2 panel,[143] similar to how a unique pressblech design on the Valsgärde 6 helmet was likely used in repair.[172] Fragment (a) for example shows groups of parallel raised lines running in correspondence "with changes of angle or direction in the modelled surface, which on the analogy of the Sutton Hoo and other rider scenes in Vendel art, strongly suggest the body of a horse."[173] Though smaller, fragment (d) shows similar patterns and suggests a similar interpretation.[143] Fragment (b), meanwhile, shows "two concentric raised lines two millimetres apart," and "appears to be a segment of the rim of a shield which would be of the same diameter as that held by the rider in design 2."[174]

The theory of design 3 as a replacement panel gains some support from damage towards the back of the helmet, yet is contradicted by the placement of fragment (c). The crest, complete for 25.5 cm (10.0 in) from front to back, is missing 2 cm (0.79 in) above the rear dragon head.[175] This head is itself mostly missing, and was entirely omitted from the 1945–46 reconstruction.[176][177][178] These missing portions are offered by Bruce-Mitford as a possible indication that the helmet at one time suffered damage necessitating the restoration of at least one design 2 panel with a new equestrian scene.[179] This theory does not explain why the rear crest and dragon head would not have been themselves repaired, however, and it is not helped by fragment (c). This fragment is an edge piece placed in the 1970–71 reconstruction on the dexter rear of the helmet at the bottom left of a panel where either design 2 or design 3 is expected, yet is "an isolated element quite out of context with any other surviving fragment and with what appears to be the subject matter of the design 3 panel."[174] Bruce-Mitford suggests that as it is an edge piece it may have originally been a scrap placed under another piece to fill a gap, for it is "otherwise inexplicable."[174][note 10]

Design 4: Larger interlace[edit]

Occurring on the cheek guards, the neck guard and the skull cap,[146] the larger interlace pattern was capable of a complete reconstruction.[181] Unlike the two identified figural scenes, partial die impressions of design 4 were used in addition to full die impressions.[181] Blank spaces on the skull cap and neck guard, devoid of decorative designs, allowed for impressions of design 4 "that are either complete or nearly so."[182] On the cheek guards, by contrast, which are irregularly shaped and fully decorated, "the interlace designs are trimmed and sometimes turned on edge to fill awkward spaces."[183]

Design 4 depicts "a single quadruped in ribbon style."[184]

Design 5: Smaller interlace[edit]

The smaller interlace pattern covered the face mask, was used prominently on the neck guard, and filled in several empty spaces on the cheek guards.[181] It is a zoomorphic design, like the larger interlace, and shows "two animals, upside down and reversed in relation to each other, whose backward-turning heads lie towards the centre of the panel."[185]

Function[edit]

With a brow band, nose-to-nape band, and lateral bands, the twelfth-century crown of Saint Stephen has a similar basic construction to some Anglo-Saxon helmets.

The Sutton Hoo helmet was both a functional piece of battle equipment and a symbol of its owner's power and prestige. It would have offered considerable protection if ever used in battle,[186] and at the same time, being the richest known Anglo-Saxon helmet, would have indicated its owner's status.[187] As it is older than the man with whom it was buried, the helmet may also have been an heirloom,[188][179] symbolic of the ceremonies of its owner's life and death;[189][190][191] it may further be a progenitor of crowns, known in Europe since around the twelfth century,[192][193] indicating both a leader's right to rule and his connection with the gods.[194]

Whether or not the helmet was ever worn in battle is unknown, but though delicately ornamented, it would have done the job well.[186] Other than leaving spaces to allow movement of the shoulders and arms, the helmet leaves its wearer's head entirely protected,[176] and unlike any other known helmet of its general type, it has a face mask, one-piece cap, and solid neck guard.[195] The iron and silver crest would have helped deflect the force of falling blows,[196][197][198] and holes underneath the nose would have created a breathable—if stifling[199]—environment within.[200] If two suppositions are to be taken as true—that damage to the back of the helmet occurred before the burial,[201] and that Raedwald is properly identified as the helmet's owner—then the helmet can be at least described as one that saw some degree of use during its lifetime, and that was owned by a person who saw battle;[202] according to Bede, around 616 Raedwald defeated Æthelfrith of Northumbria in the Battle of the River Idle.[203]

Beyond its functional purpose, the Sutton Hoo helmet would have served to convey the high status of its owner. Little more than an iron cap, such as the helmets from Shorwell and Wollaston,[204][205][206] would be needed if one only sought to protect one's head.[207][208] Yet helmets were also objects of prestige in Anglo-Saxon England, as indicated by archaeological, literary, and historical evidence.[209] Helmets are relatively common in Beowulf, an Anglo-Saxon poem focused on royals and their aristocratic milieu,[210][211][212] but rarely found today; only six are currently known, despite the excavation of thousands of graves from the period.[213][214][215] Much as this could also be reflective of poor rates of artefact survival, or even recognition—the Shorwell helmet was at first misidentified as a "fragmentary iron vessel",[216] the Wollaston helmet as a bucket,[217] and a plain Roman helmet from Burgh Castle as "cauldron fragments"[218]—the extreme scarcity suggests that helmets were never deposited in great numbers, and signified the importance of those wearing them.[215]

That the Sutton Hoo helmet was likely around 100 years old when buried suggests that it may also have been an heirloom, a sample from the royal treasury passed down from another generation.[188][179][219] The same suggestion has been made for the shield from the burial, as both it and the helmet are objects with distinct Swedish influence.[220][221][222][223] The importance of heirloom items is well documented in poetry;[224] every sword of note in Beowulf, from Hrunting to Nægling, has such a history,[225] and the poem's hero, whose own pyre is stacked with helmets,[226] uses his dying words to bestow upon his follower Wiglaf a gold collar, byrnie, and gilded helmet.[227][228] The passing of the helmet, from warrior to warrior and then to the ground, would have been symbolic of the larger ceremony of the passing of titles and power,[189][190] and the final elegy for the man buried in the mound.[191]

The helmet easily outstrips all other known examples in terms of richness.[229][230][187] It is uniquely from a presumed royal burial,[229] at a time when the monarchy was defined by the helmet and the sword.[231][232] Helmets, perhaps because they were worn by rulers so frequently, may have come to be identified as crowns.[215][233] Though many intermediate stages in the typological and functional evolution are yet unknown,[234] the earliest European crowns that survive, such as the turn-of-the-millennium crown of Saint Stephen and of Constance of Aragon, share the same basic construction of many helmets, including the Coppergate example, contemporaneous with the one from Sutton Hoo: a brow band, a nose-to-nape band, and lateral bands.[193] A divine right to rule, or at least a connection between gods and leader—also seen on earlier Roman helmets, which sometimes represented Roman gods[235]—may also have been implied by the alteration to the sinister eyebrow on the Sutton Hoo helmet; the one-eyed appearance could only have been visible in low light, such as when its wearer was in a hall, the seat of the king's power.[194]

Context and parallels[edit]

Unique in many respects, the Sutton Hoo helmet is nevertheless inextricably linked to its Anglo-Saxon and Scandinavian contexts. It is one of only six known Anglo-Saxon helmets, along with those found at Benty Grange, Coppergate, Wollaston, Shorwell and Staffordshire,[214] yet is closer in character to those from Vendel and Valsgärde.[236] At the same time, the helmet shares "consistent and intimate" parallels with those characterised in the Anglo-Saxon epic Beowulf,[237] and, like the Sutton Hoo ship-burial as a whole,[238] has had a profound impact on modern understandings of the poem.[239]

Helmets[edit]

Within the corpus of sixth and seventh century helmets, the Sutton Hoo helmet is broadly classified as a "crested helmet,"[240][241] distinct from the continental spangenhelm[242][243] and lamellenhelm.[244][245] 50 helmets are so classified,[240][246][note 11] although barely more than a dozen can be reconstructed[252] and a few are so degraded that they are not indisputably from helmets.[248][241] Excepting an outlier fragment found in Kiev;[253] all crested helmets originate from England or Scandinavia.[254][255]

Of the crested helmets the Sutton Hoo helmet belongs to the Vendel and Valsgärde class, which themselves derive from the Roman infantry and cavalry helmets of the fourth and fifth century Constantinian workshops.[256] Helmets were found in graves 1, 12 and 14 at Vendel (in addition to partial helmets in graves 10 and 11), and in graves 5, 6, 7 and 8 at Valsgärde.[137] The Sutton Hoo example shares similarities in design, yet "is richer and of higher quality" than its Scandinavian analogues;[257] its differences may reflect its manufacture for someone of higher social status, or its closer temporal proximity to the antecedent Roman helmets.[258]
